_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Fairway Facility

Enterprise Products Operating LLC.

Executive Summary

Risk Management Plan



EPA Identifier:  1000 0022 4633



Accidental Release Prevention and Response



Enterprise Products Operating, LLC, has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of the facility's processes.  It is the practice of Enterprise Products Operating LLC (Enterprise) to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of substances. However, if a release does occur, trained personnel will respond to, control and contain the release.





Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances



The Fairway Facility is located at 260 FM 3153 near San Augustine, Texas in San Augustine County at the global position of 31.50710? N and -94.3423? W.   

The facility operates a refrigeration process to produce petroleum products (e.g., natural gas, propane, butane, and condensate) from oil and gas wells. Regulated flammables handled at the Fairway Gas Plant include methane, ethane, propane and butane.  Enterprise Products purchased the facility from Azure Midstream and assumed control of the Fairway Facility on May 1, 2017.

Due to the presence of regulated flammable materials above the threshold quantity, the Fairway Facility is registered as an EPA Risk Management Program 3 facility.





Offsite Consequence Analysis Results



The offsite consequence analysis will not be reflected in the executive summary but rather is reflected in the data components.  There are flammable substances on site, but no toxic substances above the threshold quantity.  



General Accident Release Prevention Program



The following is a summary of the safety and accident prevention program in place at the Fairway Facility.  The gas processing operations at the Fairway Facility are regu

lated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) regulation, and are also subject to the OSHA PSM Standard.  This summary addresses each of the PSM program elements and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program.







Safe Work Practices



The Fairway Facility has long standing safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety.  Examples of these include: (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, (2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous substances before process piping and equipment is opened, (4) a permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities (i.e., hot work) and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space.  These procedures, along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely



Incident Investigation



The Fairway Facility will promptly investigate any incidents that result in or reasonably could result in a fire/explosion, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to gather the facts, determine the root cause, and develop corrective action to prevent the reoccurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team will document its findings, develop recommendation(s) to prevent a reoccurrence and forward these results to the business management team for resolution.



Specialized Safety Features



The Fairway Facility has safety features and controls to help contain/control a release, to quickly detect a release and reduce the consequence of a release. The following types of safety features are used in the covered processes:





Release Detection



* The operators are observant for anything that may crea

te a leak.





Release Containment and Control



* Process relief valves that discharge to a flare/vent system to handle episodic releases

* Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automated)

* Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameter (e.g., high level, high temperature)

* Curbing or diking to contain liquid releases

* Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system, backup firewater pump)

* Atmospheric relief devices



Release Mitigation



* Fire suppression and extinguishing systems

* Trained emergency first-responder personnel

* Personal protective equipment

* Spacing of equipment in accordance with IRI spacing guideline.

* Emergency shutdowns strategically placed around the plant that automatically shuts in the inlet and outlet and blows the plant down through the vent system.





Five Year Accident History



Over the past five years there have been no large or small releases which resulted in any injuries, property damage or offsite consequences.





Emergency Procedures Information



The Fairway Facility maintains a written emergency procedure, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The procedures are for the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address notification of local emergency response agencies if a release occurs. Employees receive training in emergency procedures.  The emergency procedure is updated when necessary based on modifications made to the plant facilities.



The overall emergency procedure program for the Fairway Facility is coordinated with the San Augustine County Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC). The Fairway Facility has around-the- clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department).  This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if

necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, the Fairway Facility will conduct periodic emergency drills that involve the LEPC and emergency response organizations, and will provide periodic refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the plant.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Enterprise Products Operating, LLC is committed to the safe design and operation of all of its processing and fractionation plants and liquid hydrocarbon terminals and resolves all findings from PHA's, some of which result in modifications to the storage and loading operations.  Additionally, employee recommendations to improve the safety of the storage and loading operations are reviewed and implemented if they are judged to be effective in improving terminal safety or reducing accident risk.
